ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK TAR: TRA 34300
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
FOR THE
2000-2002 ORIENTATION PROGRAM FOR OFFICIALS
OF
ADB's DEVELOPING MEMBER COUNTRIES
August 2000

ABBREVIATIONS
ADB – Asian Development Bank
BPHR – Human Resources Division
DMC – developing member country
TA – technical assistance
NOTE
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.

I.  INTRODUCTION
1.  The Asian Development Bank has conducted an orientation program for government
officials from selected developing member countries (DMCs) annually since 1989, except in
1996.1 The program has provided the participants with carefully designed in-house training
involving (i) exposure to ADB policies and procedures, (ii) introduction to selected aspects of
development planning, (iii) discussion of project management skills, and (iv) awareness of
ADB's  changing  role.  The  participants  were  generally  midlevel  government  officials  with
experience in managing development work.. This technical assistance (TA) will meet the costs
of continuing the program for the three years from 2000 to 2002.2  The TA framework is
presented in Appendix 1.
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE
2.  The program helps participants upgrade their skills, particularly in development planning,
and manage development activities in their countries. It provides an opportunity for participants
to become more familiar with ADB policies and procedures, and ADB’s activities in the DMCs.
The program also promotes goodwill between ADB and participating DMCs.  A total of 168
participants  from  32  DMCs  have  benefited  from  the  Program:  (Appendix  2  presents  the
distribution of participants by year and country).
3.  Other programs available for officials of DMCs and staff of executing agencies are
scheduled to impart skills related to economic analysis and project management. The scope,
coverage, and duration of such programs are different from that proposed in this report.
4.  Participants in the 1999 program were surveyed regarding the program's merits. They
noted that the concept was fundamentally sound, and that they returned to their countries with a
better understanding of ADB’s operations and policies. They also interacted closely with ADB
staff who are working with their countries. A parallel and useful outcome of the program was
that participants learned about other countries and culture; an experience that is of value
particularly  to  participants  engaged  in  regional  economic  cooperation  activities.  An  alumni
program has been established to strengthen the network of participants and ADB. The program
participants will regularly receive the ADB Review and an updated alumni directory.
5.  The  survey  suggested  several  areas  that  can  be  improved.  To  maximize  the
understanding of the participants, learning will be more interactive and more opportunities will
be available to meet with ADB staff. To assure that the program is tailored to the needs of the
participants, they may be involved in program design at an earlier stage than was the case in
the past.
                                                
1  The title Orientation Program replaced the title Special Secondment Scheme, which was used from 1990 to 1995.
2 The TA was listed in ADB Business Opportunities on 24 May 2000.

2
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Objectives
6. The objectives of the 2000-2002 program are to :
(i)  increase familiarity of counterpart officials with ADB’s policies, procedures, and
operations;
(ii)  improve participants’ skills in planning and managing development activities;
(iii)  enhance the relationship between ADB and the DMC counterpart agencies; and
(iv)  enhance the DMCs’ understanding of ADB's changing role.
B. Scope
7.  The program, which will be held annually over the three years from 2000 to 2002, will
support approximately 25 participants each year from selected DMCs for up to three weeks at
ADB headquarters.  Participants will be from organizations in DMCs that borrow from ADB
and/or are acting as counterparts to ADB in implementing ADB-financed projects and programs.
Each of the selected DMCs will be invited to send one official for the Orientation Program. The
nominees should be government officials at the level of director or deputy director of a division
(or equivalent), preferably from planning agencies, the ministry of finance, or other central
ministries. All participants must have a working knowledge of English.
8.  Based on previous success, the current program will have several sets of learning
opportunities taking into account the needs of the participants and the accommodative capacity
of the various ADB departments and offices.
9.  Briefing sessions on ADB’s major operational policies and procedures will include (i) an
introduction to ADB strategies and the new role for ADB (6 days), (ii) procurement operations
(1.5  days),  (iii)  consulting  services  (1  day),  (iv)  disbursement  operations  (1.5  days),  (v)
consultation with departments (3 days), and (vi) visits to an international organization and ADB
project sites.
10.  The sessions will include several case studies dealing with such issues as consultant
selection and will be based on ADB’s day-to-day experiences.  The Capacity Building Unit of the
Strategy and Policy Department will be closely consulted in designing the program to contribute
to the capacity- building component.
11.  In addition to the regular sessions, the participants may visit counterpart divisions so
they can discuss issues and deepen their understanding of ADB’s operations. The Human
Resources Division (BPHR) will arrange meetings in cooperation with the divisions concerned.
12.  To increase the learning impact, the participants will be encouraged to become involved
in the program before the meetings start.  Issues of interest in ADB’s operations and the
expectations  of  the  participants  will  be  incorporated  into  the  course  content,  design,  and
delivery.  Operational  departments  are  expected  to  play  an  important  role  in  disseminating
information about the latest policy developments to the participants.

3
13.  During  the  program,  ADB  will  organize  study  tours  so  participants  can  visit  other
international organizations operating in the Philippines, such as the International Rice Research
Institute, and ADB-financed projects being implemented in the Philippines.
C. Cost Estimates and Financing Plan
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $750,000 (Appendix 3). The TA will be financed
by ADB on a grant basis from the ADB-funded TA Program and will provide round-trip airfare
(economy class), accommodation, and per diem for each participant. The participating DMC
governments will grant leaves of absence to their participants in the training program and
continue to pay their salaries during the program.
D. Implementation Arrangements
15.  ADB will be assisted in implementing the TA by an international consultant for six
person-weeks  for  each  orientation  program.  The  consultant  must  be  knowledgeable  about
ADB’s operations, procedures, and organization, and will organize the briefing sessions in
coordination with the departments/offices concerned (with proper balance between the projects
and  programs  departments),  prepare  the  case  studies,  and  arrange  the  details  of  the
participants’ assignments with their counterpart divisions. Outline terms of reference for the
consultant are attached as Appendix 4. The consultant will be selected in accordance with
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.  The administrative, secretarial services, and
logistical arrangements will be provided by a seminar assistant (locally recruited consultant) who
will be hired for 2 person-months.
16.  The  Orientation  Program  will  commence  in  November  each  year.  ADB  will  be  the
Executing  Agency  and  BPHR  will  administer  the  TA  in  close  consultation  with  concerned
operational departments/offices within ADB. Participants will be selected by BPHR in close
consultation with the counterpart divisions mainly in operational departments. The estimated
completion date is December 2002.
17. At the end of the program, participants will evaluate the usefulness of the course, and
the logistical and administrative arrangements. Their feedback will help BPHR improve the
program for the following year.
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION
18. The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the
provision of technical assistance, on a grant basis, in an amount not exceeding the equivalent of
$750,000 for the purpose of 2000-2002 Orientation Program for Officials of ADB’s Developing
Member Countries and hereby reports such action to the Board.

Appendix 4
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR THE CONSULTANT
1.  An  internationally  recruited  consultant  will  prepare  and  implement  the  Orientation
Program for officials of the Asian Development Bank’s developing member countries over 6
person-weeks for each orientation program. The consultant must be familiar with ADB’s policies
and procedures, and should have previous experience in organizing training activities and/or
seminars or workshops.
2. The work of the consultant will include, but will not necessarily be limited to briefing
sessions, case studies, assignment plans, field trips, and administrative arrangements for the
program.
3.  Briefing sessions. The consultant will organize and implement the following briefing
sessions, in coordination with the departments/offices concerned
(i)  Introduction to ADB Operations,
(ii)  Procurement Operations,
(iii)  Consulting Services, and
(iv)  Disbursement Operations
4. The consultant will schedule the lectures of the briefing sessions and identify suitable
resource persons.  Supported by the Human Resources Division (BPHR), the consultant will
also be responsible for the administrative arrangement of the sessions.
5. Case studies. In consultation with the departments/offices concerned, the consultant will
prepare  case  studies  based  on  ADB’s  work  experience.  These  case  studies  will  give
participants an opportunity to become actively involved in the learning process and to obtain
hands-on  experience  with  ADB’s  daily  work.  The  consultant  will  evaluate  the  participants’
recommendations and discuss potential solutions with them.
6.  Assignment plans. In consultation with the counterpart divisions of ADB, the consultant
will prepare the plans for the assignment of the participants to the divisions.
7. Field  Trip.  The  consultant  will  identify  international  organizations  in  the  Philippines
whose operations can be studied by the participants, and arrange a one-day study tour to one
such organization. The consultant will also arrange for a visit to 1-2 ADB-financed projects in the
Philippines and for discussions with the ministries and the executing agencies involved.
8. Administrative Arrangements. In cooperation with BPHR staff, the consultant will make
all  of  the  administrative  arrangements  necessary  during  the  assignment  period  of  the
participants.  In  particular,  the  consultant  will  prepare  materials  to  brief  former  program
participants with recent ADB developments.
